descriptionSet.description: The movie "Aladdin and the wonderfull lamp" was directed by Homi Wadia and got released in 1952. Mahipal, who is playing the role of Aladdin in this movie, can be seen in laughing about an elerly couple standing in front of him. A few other people are standing behind them. All persons depicted are wearing oriental kind of clothes.

inscription.text: Wadia Brothers Production Produced and Directed by Homi Wadia

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

hra:item.hra:value: text-en: Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp
text-en: Wadia Brothers Production Produced and Directed by Homi Wadia

description-en: The movie "Aladdin and the wonderfull lamp" was directed by Homi Wadia and got released in 1952. Mahipal, who is playing the role of Aladdin in this movie, can be seen in laughing about an elerly couple standing in front of him. A few other people are standing behind them. All persons depicted are wearing oriental kind of clothes. (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The success of Homi Wadiaâ€™s Aladdin kick-started a new vogue for fantasy films on the B and C circuits. By the mid-1950s these and costume films together accounted for around a third of all productions. (Rosie Thomas)(gs)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: In the context of the movie it becomes clear, that the depicted persons are Aladdin's parents and one of his brothers standing behind him. (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: This lobby card is especially intriguing, with a dozen or so faces looking intently outwards but not a hint of what has amused, amazed or confused this family group. One assumes this scene of cosy domesticity was chosen as a reassuring space into which potential cinema-goers could project their fantasy selves as audience. (Rosie Thomas)(gs)
related literature: Irwin, Robert 1994. "The Arabian Nights: A Companion". London: Allen Lane. (gs)
related literature: Marzolph, Ulrich 2006. "Arabian Nights Reader". Detroit: Wayne State University Press. (gs)
related literature: Said, Edward 1995. "Orientalism". London: Penguin Books. (gs)
related literature: Thomas, Rosie 2010. "Still Magic. An Aladdin's Cave of 1950s B-Movie Fantasy" http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/103/index.html (26.11.2010) (gs)
